questions.text: 1. A 70-year-old man with Alzheimer's disease was brought by his daughter for a consultation, as he is unable to understand written instructions and pictures. He also forgets the names of common objects. He has no difficulty in speaking, and his comprehension of speech is intact. Which part of the cerebral cortex is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The angular gyrus is affected in this patient.

The inability to name objects and the inability to understand written instructions and pictures suggest anomic aphasia, which is seen with lesions in the angular gyrus. This is because visual information is not processed and transmitted to the Wernicke area.

The angular gyrus processes information from words that are read in such a way that they can be converted into the auditory forms of the words in Wernicke's area. When a lesion damages the angular gyrus, without affecting Wernicke or Broca areas:

* Speech is intact

* Comprehension is intact

* Repetition is intact

* Confrontation naming impaired (there is difficulty in understanding written language or pictures)

* Word-finding and spelling are impaired. 

The lesion sites can be anywhere within the left hemisphere language network, including the angular gyrus, middle and inferior temporal gyri. Anomic aphasia is commonly seen in the following conditions:

* Alzheimer's disease

* Metabolic encephalopathy

* Head trauma

Other options:

Option B: Wernicke’s area is located at the parieto-temporal junction. A lesion here causes fluent aphasia. The speech itself is normal but it is full of jargon and neologisms that make little sense. The patient also fails to comprehend the meaning of spoken or written words, so other aspects of the use of language are compromised.

Option C: Lesions at the superior temporal gyrus cause pure word deafness. Comprehension of spoken language and repetition is impaired. Naming and fluency is preserved. Most commonly due to bilateral or left-sided MCA strokes

Option D: Lesions at the right inferior temporal lobe can cause prosopagnosia, which is the inability to recognize faces. The storage and recognition of faces are strongly represented in the right inferior temporal lobe in right-handed individuals.

Pearl PM2326: Brodmann areas

44 and 45 - Broca’s(Motor speech) area Inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere

41 and 42 - 

Primary auditory area

 Superior surface of the superior temporal gyrus(Heschl’s gyrus)
22* - Wernicke’s(Sensory speech) area Superior temporal gyrus
17 - Primary visual(striate) area Walls and floor of the posterior part of calcarine sulcus (postcalcarine sulcus) in the occipital lobe

18 and 19- 

Visual association area

*There is uncertainty about the extent of the Wernicke's area. Some authorities consider areas 39 and 40 as part of Wernicke's area in addition to area 22.

Pearl PM0908: Aphasias and Related Conditions

Broca's Preserved Impaired Impaired Decreased

Posterior (fluent) transcortical Impaired Preserved Impaired Preserved

questions.text: 2. A woman with a history of bulimia nervosa presents to the OPD with complaints of dizziness. She admits to abusing diuretics for the past 2 weeks. On examination, her blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg. With respect to fluid volume and plasma sodium, which of the following changes are likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Increased ECF, increased ICF, and decreased plasma sodium
Decreased ECF, decreased ICF, and increased plasma sodium
Decreased ECF, increased ICF, and decreased plasma sodium
Increased ECF, decreased ICF, and increased plasma sodium

questions.solution:
Diuresis results in decreased ECF, increased ICF, and reduced plasma sodium, leading to hypoosmotic volume contraction.

Diuresis causes loss of both water and sodium, with a greater proportion of water being excreted. This triggers the release of vasopressin, which facilitates the reabsorption of free water in the collecting ducts. Consequently, plasma osmolarity becomes hypotonic, causing fluid to shift into the intracellular compartment to restore osmolar balance.

As a result, the  ICF volume increases, while the ECF volume remains low due to both translocation to the ICF and diuretic loss. Despite the reduced ECF volume, plasma sodium levels are also low.

Diuretic overuse → Sodium & water loss → ↓ECF volume, ↓ECF osmolarity → Water shifts into cells → ↑ICF volume + ↓Plasma Na⁺.

A similar picture is seen in adrenal insufficiency.  In adrenal insufficiency, the key defect is aldosterone deficiency (low mineralocorticoid activity):

* ↓ Aldosterone → ↓ Na⁺ reabsorption + ↑ Na⁺ loss in urine → ↓ECF sodium content → ↓ECF volume.

* Plasma osmolarity falls (hyponatremia) because Na⁺ is the main ECF osmole.

* Hypoosmolar ECF draws water into ICF → ↑ICF volume. 

Diuretic abuse has been documented in patients with bulimia and in athletes. It is often driven by the desire for rapid weight loss, fluid depletion, or meeting weight-class requirements. In bulimia, diuretic misuse often coexists with laxative abuse and vomiting, compounding risks. In athletes, it is considered doping and carries both medical and legal consequences.

Other Options:

Option A: This is seen in cases of hypoosmotic volume expansion like in the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) and bronchogenic tumors. 

SIADH is associated with euvolemic hyponatremia. This leads to a decrease in the osmolarity of the ECF. This causes a fluid shift from the ECF to the ICF until the osmolarity of both compartments becomes equal. The fluid influx also leads to a decrease in the ICF's osmolarity. Therefore, the net effect is an increase in extracellular volume, an increase in intracellular volume, and a fall in osmolarity in both compartments.

Option B: This is seen in cases of hyperosmotic volume contraction like in diabetes insipidus and excessive sweating.

Option D: This is seen in cases of hyperosmotic volume expansion like in high NaCl intake. The addition of excess NaCl to ECF pulls the fluid from ICF into the ECF. This results in a decreased volume of ICF, increased volume of ECF, and increased osmolarity in both ECF and ICF.

The illustration given below shows the Darrow-Yannet diagram in various conditions.

questions.text:
3. A 63-year-old woman is started on mechanical ventilation after presenting with acute respiratory failure. The ventilator is set to deliver a tidal volume of 500 mL at a frequency of 10 times per minute. After transferring the patient to the ICU, the physician increased the tidal volume to 600 mL without changing the respiratory rate. Considering that the patient's V/Q is normal, which of the following changes would you expect?

V/Q- Ventilation/ Perfusion ratio
questions.solution:
Increase in tidal volume causes decreased dead space fraction.

Dead space fraction refers to the fraction of each breath occupied by the anatomical dead space. The alveolar ventilation can be increased by increasing either the tidal volume or respiratory frequency or both.

Dead space fraction = Anatomical dead space / tidal volume.

When the tidal volume alone is increased, without increasing the respiratory rate, the volume of air inhaled with each breath is increased. However, since anatomical dead space remains the same, the dead space fraction is reduced.

Before change:

* Tidal volume (VT) = 500 mL:

* Dead space volume (VD) = 150 mL

* Dead space fraction (VD/VT) = 150 / 500 = 0.30 (30%)

After change:

* VT = 600 mL

* VD = 150 mL (unchanged in absolute terms)

* Dead space fraction (VD/VT) = 150 / 600 = 0.25 (25%)

If V/Q is normal, then physiological dead space = anatomical dead space (the above calculation holds true).

If the respiratory rate alone is increased, without a change in tidal volume, then alveolar ventilation increases. However, since both tidal volume and anatomical dead space remain the same, there is no change in dead space fraction.

Other options:

Option A: Anatomical dead space refers to the volume of all the space of the respiratory system other than the alveoli, that do not participate in gas exchange. The anatomical dead space is not altered with a change in ventilation.

Option B: Alveolar dead space refers to the volume of gas in the alveoli that does not equilibrate with the blood, as in patients with poor perfusion. However, in the given case, the patient has a normal ventilation-perfusion ratio. Therefore, there is no change in alveolar dead space.

Option C: Physiological dead space is the sum of anatomical dead space and alveolar dead space. In the given case, physiological dead space remains unaltered.

questions.text: 4. A 60-year-old man presents with sudden, wild flailing of the right side of the body. A lesion at which of the following sites is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The lesion at site 3 will most likely cause these symptoms.

Sudden, wild flailing of one side of the body suggests the movement disorder, hemiballismus, due to a lesion at the contralateral subthalamic nucleus.

Hemiballismus is caused by a lesion in the contralateral subthalamic nucleus, most often due to lacunar infarct (small vessel stroke). Management includes dopamine-depleting or blocking agents (e.g., tetrabenazine, haloperidol) and treating the underlying cause; symptoms often improve spontaneously over time.





Other options:

Option A: Lesions at the striatum of basal ganglia (site 1)(caudate nucleus, putamen) would present with movement disorders such as chorea, which are sudden and purposeless jerky movements.

Option B: Lesions at the globus pallidus (site 2) would present with athetosis. Athetosis is slow writhing movements that are snakelike, especially in the fingers.

Option D: Lesions in the substantia nigra (site 4) would present with pill-rolling tremors of Parkinson's disease seen at rest. These tremors decrease upon intentional movement.

  • Anxiety 
  • Hyperthyroidism 
Asterixis Cortex Inability to sustain a muscle contraction while performing a complex motor movement

Hemibalismus Subthalamic nucleus Unilateral wild flinging violent movement of large proximal joints

questions.text: 5. A 35-year-old man has been drinking rum almost daily for the last 10 years. He comes to the emergency department with complaints of vomiting blood. His abdomen is distended. The doctor administers a vasopressin analogue. Which second messenger system does this drug act through?
questions.solution:
The drug in this scenario acts via phospholipase C.

The clinical scenario of a chronic alcoholic patient presenting with hematemesis is suggestive of esophageal varices. Vasopressin analogues used in the management of esophageal varices to reduce bleeding act through the V1A receptor on vascular smooth muscle via phospholipase C.  

Vasopressin mediates its effect via 3 kinds of receptors- V1a, V1b and V2. All three receptors are G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs). 

G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are cell membrane receptors that span across the membrane 7 times. They also serve as receptors for various peptide hormones, neurotransmitters, amino acids, etc.

Subtypes of GPCRs are distinguished by their alpha subunits. The important subtypes of GPCRs are Gs, Gi, Gq, and Go.

GPCRs act via various second messengers. The important ones with their action on the effector are:

* Gs causes activation of adenylyl cyclase and results in Ca2+ channel opening.

* Gi causes inhibition of adenylyl cyclase and results in K+ channel opening.

* Go causes Ca2+ channel inactivation.

Gq causes activation of phospholipase C, which generates the second messengers inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG). The water-soluble IP3 diffuses to the cytosol and mobilizes Ca2+ from endoplasmic reticulum depots.

The image given below shows the effects of phospholipase C after activation by Gq.



Pearl PM2317: Membrane receptors and their mechanisms

1. G protein coupled receptor(GPCR)

   Effect 2nd messenger  Action
Gs Activates adenylate cyclase Stimulation of cAMP production Activates protein kinase A
Gi Inhibits adenylate cyclase Inhibition of cAMP production -
Gq Activates phospholipase C Liberate DAG and IP3 which mobilize Ca2+ from endoplasmic reticulum Activates protein kinase C


2. Guanylyl cyclase receptor

Effector 2nd messenger
Guanylyl cyclase Stimulation of cGMP production


3. Receptor tyrosine kinase

Effector 2nd messenger
Tyrosine kinase MAP kinase


4. Cytokine receptor tyrosine kinase

Effector 2nd messenger
JAK, tyrosine kinase STAT, MAP kinase


5. Serine kinase

Effector 2nd messenger

Notes: 1. Although cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed, it moves to the nucleus to initiate its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors, as they bind and become activated in the nucleus, as mentioned above. However, they have two primary sites of action: the cytoplasm and the nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text:
6. A mother brings her baby with complaints of decreased movements for the past 2 months. On examination, the child appeared floppy. Which of the following features if present, makes spinal muscular atrophy as the likely diagnosis?

* Spasticity

* Exaggerated reflexes

* Flaccidity

* Tongue fasciculations

* Hypotonia
questions.solution:
Spinal muscular atrophy is a type of lower motor neuron lesion. Therefore, the baby will have flaccidity, tongue fasciculations, and hypotonia.

In spinal muscular atrophy, there is a mutation of the SMN1 gene which results in the degeneration of lower motor neurons. The affected patient will have symmetric weakness, flaccid paralysis, fasciculations, hyporeflexia, and muscle atrophy. 

Lower motor neurons are the neurons whose axons terminate on the skeletal muscles. Damage to these neurons will lead to :

* flaccid paralysis

* muscular atrophy

* fasciculations- visible muscle twitches that appear as flickers under the skin

* hypotonia- decreased muscle tone

* hyporeflexia or areflexia.

Important examples of lower motor neuron lesions are poliomyelitis, spinal muscular atrophy, and Bell's palsy.

Upper motor neurons typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor neurons and brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons. Lesions to these neurons lead to:

* spasticity 

* hypertonia

* hyperactive stretch reflex 

* positive Babinski sign

* clonus

Important examples of upper motor neuron lesions are stroke and primary lateral sclerosis.

Babinski sign- The Babinski sign is a dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of the other toes when the lateral aspect of the sole of the foot is scratched. The normal response is the plantar flexion in all toes. 

Mechanism- It is based on the principle that stimulation of the S1 dermatome stimulates the S1 myotome that is responsible for the plantar flexion. Whenever the corticospinal tract is damaged the stimulation also spreads to the L4 and L5 myotomes, resulting in the contraction of toe extensors like extensor hallucis longus and extensor digitorum longus. Below image shows Babinski's sign:



In infants whose corticospinal tracts are not well developed, dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of the other toes is the natural response to stimuli applied to the sole of the foot. The image below shows a normal response in an infant.



Pearl PM0840: Features of Motor Neuron Lesions

Upper Motor Neuron Lesion

Lower Motor Neuron Lesion

Upper motor neuron typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor neurons, but they can also include brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons

Lower motor neurons are those whose axons terminate on skeletal muscles

Little or no muscle wasting → weakness of relatively large group of muscles

Muscle atrophy → muscle weakness of an individual and specific muscle

Hypertonia

Hypotonia

Increased or exaggerated deep tendon reflexes (hyperreflexia)

Hyporeflexia or areflexia

Spasticity

Flaccidity

Positive Babinski sign (abnormal plantar extensor reflex)

Fasciculations

questions.text: 7. A patient presents with dizziness and fatigue. His ECG shows dropped beats after every 3 PR intervals. Which of the following is true about his condition?

choices.text: Ventricular rate is lower than the atrial rate

questions.solution:
The true statement in the given condition is that the ventricular rate is lower than the atrial rate.

The description of dropped beats after every 3 PR intervals suggests a type of second-degree heart block. In second-degree heart block, not all atrial impulses are conducted to the ventricles. So, the ventricular rate is lower than the atrial rate.

A second degree heart block can be of two types:

* Mobitz type I (Wenckebach)- In this condition, the PR interval is progressively prolonged until a beat is dropped (i.e., a QRS complex is missing).

* Mobitz type 2 - In this condition, the PR interval remains fixed, however, some P waves are not conducted.

The ventricular rate is lower than the atrial rate in both these conditions, resulting in fewer ventricular contractions compared to atrial contractions.

The following image shows the waves, intervals, and segments of a normal ECG:



PR interval represents atrio-ventricular conductions and atrial repolarisation. Normal PR interval is 0.12-0.2 seconds. Abnormalities in this interval point to the presence of a heart block. 

Other options:

Option B: This option is incorrect as second degree heart blocks typically show normal QRS complexes.

Option C: Second degree heart blocks are not associated with a high incidence of ventricular tachycardia. 

Option D: In second degree heart block, due to the lost beat, there is an overall decrease in the stroke volume. Thus this option is not entirely correct and Option A is more appropriate.

Pearl PM1204: Types of Heart block

questions.text: 8. A patient with low hemoglobin levels is diagnosed with pernicious anemia. Deficiency of a glycoprotein causes this condition. Identify the cell that secretes this glycoprotein among the gastric gland cells marked in the image below.
questions.solution:
The cells marked as 2 secrete the glycoprotein deficient in the given clinical scenario.

The cells marked as 2 are parietal cells and they are responsible for the secretion of a glycoprotein called intrinsic factor. Deficiency of intrinsic factor results in pernicious anaemia.

Parietal cells, also called oxyntic cells are more numerous in the upper half of the gastric glands. They are characterized by the presence of canaliculi. These cells have numerous mitochondria and are actively involved in the secretion of hydrochloric acid and intrinsic factor - a glycoprotein that must be present for adequate absorption of vitamin B12 from the ileum. 

Intrinsic factor combines with vitamin B12 in the stomach and protects it from being digested and destroyed as it passes into the small intestine. Then, when the intrinsic factor–vitamin B12 complex reaches the terminal ileum, the intrinsic factor binds with receptors on the ileal epithelial surface, which makes it possible for vitamin B12 to be absorbed.

In the absence of intrinsic factor, only a small amount of vitamin B12 is absorbed. In addition, without intrinsic factor, an adequate amount of vitamin B12 is not made available from the foods to cause young, newly forming red blood cells to mature in the bone marrow. This gives rise to pernicious anemia.



The following image shows vitamin B12 absorption:



Other options:

Option A: The cells marked as 1 are mucous neck cells, which are located near the upper end or "neck" of the gastric glands and secrete mucous.

Option C: The cells marked as 3  are the enterochromaffin-like cell (ECL) which are present near the basal part of gastric glands and lie between the chief cells and the basement membrane. The function of this cell is to release histamine which in turn stimulates the parietal cells to secrete HCL. The ECL is stimulated by gastrin secreted by G cells from the pylorus and acetylcholine secreted by the vagus.

Option D: The cells marked as 4 are chief cells which are numerous in the basal part of the main gastric glands. Their cells are cuboidal or low columnar, which secrete pepsinogen and gastric lipase.

Pearl PM1277: Cells of the Gastric Glands

HCl

Intrinsic factor

Gastrin

Vagal stimulation (Ach)

Histamine

Fundus, Body

Pepsinogen

Gastric lipase

Vagal stimulation

Mucous cells

Antrum, cardia, pylorus

Mucous

Vagal stimulation

G cells

Antrum

Gastrin

Vagal stimulation (via GRP)

Oligopeptides

Inhibited by somatostatin

Inhibited by H+ in stomach

Enterochromaffin like cells (ECL)

Fundus

questions.text: 9. A 40-year-old man undergoes ileal resection for refractive Crohn's disease not improving with medication. He suffers from steatorrhea later on, which occurs most likely because_____
questions.solution:
Steatorrhea occurs most likely due to hampered micelle formation.

Fat absorption is facilitated by micelle formation by the action of bile. A lot of bile is re-used due to enterohepatic circulation. When ileum is resected, liver cannot cope up with so much bile production, as a result, micelle formation is hampered and fat absorption is decreased. This excess of fat is lost via feces giving rise to steatorrhea.

Enterohepatic circulation is necessary for the secretion of bile salts. Bile acts as an emulsifying agent (separate the fat in small particles). Action of bile results in micelle formation. Micelles are cylindrical disks with core of digested lipid and outer surface lines by bile salts. These micelles solubilize and carries the lipid to intestinal lumen for absorption.

However, in some individuals, steatorrhea may not result despite absence of micelles because the intestine has a large absorptive surface area, this is referred to as anatomic reserve.

The enterohepatic circulation of bile salts is the recycling of bile salts between the small intestine (terminal ileum) and the liver by means of the portal vein. It occurs 6-8 times a day. The recirculation of bile salts to the liver reduces the demand to synthesize new bile salts.





Other options:

Option B: Chylomicron formation occurs throughout small intestinal mucosa, it will be decreased a bit but is less likely to cause steatorrhea.

Option C: Digestion of triglycerides occurs by the action of pancreatic lipase, which is unaffected in this case.

Option D: Intrinsic factor absorption occurs in the ileum. Its absorption will be decreased and Vitamin B12 deficiency might occur, but it does not cause steatorrhea.

questions.text: 10. A 48-year-old man started using crutches following a road traffic accident. After the initial 2 weeks, he complained of inability to extend his wrist. He achieved complete recovery a few weeks later. What is the mechanism behind this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
This is a case of crutch palsy which is a type of neurapraxia. 

Neurapraxia is a reversible physiological block in nerve conduction. Some types of sensation and muscle power are lost in neuropraxia. The structure of the nerve is not changed and there is complete, spontaneous recovery after a few weeks. Neurapraxia occurs due to the segmental demyelination by mechanical pressure. 

Crutch palsy occurs when the radial nerve is compressed in the arm from direct pressure against a firm object (crutch). Other examples of neuropraxia include Saturday night palsy and tourniquet palsy both due to radial nerve compression. Clinical features of crutch palsy include:

Motor findings:

* Paralysis of triceps (loss of elbow extension).

* Paralysis of wrist and finger extensors - wrist drop.

* Loss of triceps jerk.

Sensory loss: Posterior arm, posterior forearm, and dorsum of hand (radial nerve distribution).

Compared to Saturday night palsy or tourniquet palsy, crutch palsy is higher up (axilla), so triceps involvement and reflex loss are characteristic.

Other options:

Option A- Neurotmesis occurs due to the damage in both axon and nerve by complete section or scarring of a segment in open fractures. A surgical nerve repair is required since spontaneous recovery is not posssible.

Option B- Axonotmesis occurs due to the damage of axons with preservation of the internal architecture of the nerve. It is seen typically after closed fractures and dislocations. Spontaneous recovery can occur but it takes months not few weeks.

Option C- Neurolysis is the surgical removal of fibrotic tissue inside a nerve trunk.



Pearl PM2200: Seddon's classification of nerve injuries

Seddon's classification includes 3 groups:

* Neuropraxia

* Axonotmesis

* Neurotmesis

Neuropraxia:

* Reversible physiologic conduction block

* Occurs due to mechanical pressure causing segmental demyelination

* Examples: Saturday night palsy, tourniquet, and crutch palsy

Axonotmesis: 

* Axonal interruption

* Conduction is lost but the nerve is in continuity and neural tubes are intact

* Examples: Closed fractures and dislocations

Neurotmesis: 

* Division of the nerve trunk

* Endoneurial tube destruction also occurs

* Example: Complete section of nerve in open fractures

Pearl PM0677: Sunderland Classification of Nerve Injuries

Degree

Pathology

Previously called

1

Blocked flow of axoplasm/ conduction block

Neuropraxia

2

Loss of axons but within its endoneurium

Axonotemesis

3

Loss of endoneurium and crossed regeneration

Neurotemesis

4

Injury to perineurium and scarring

Partial transection

5

Injury to epineurium and scarring

Complete transection

questions.text: 11. A patient was diagnosed with ependymoma arising from the filum terminale of the spinal cord. MRI revealed the destruction of both sensory and motor roots supplying the bladder. Which of the following would be seen in such a patient's bladder?

choices.text: Initially flaccid and distended bladder becomes shrunken and hypertrophied gradually
Initially shrunken and hypertrophied bladder becomes flaccid and distended
The bladder becomes distended, thin walled, and hypotonic
The bladder becomes shrunken and hypertrophied

questions.solution:
In a denervated bladder where both the afferent and efferent fibers cut off, the bladder will initially be distended but later be shrunken and hypertrophied. 

When both afferent and efferent nerves, potentially damaged by tumors of the cauda equina or filum terminale, are destroyed, the bladder initially becomes flaccid and distended. Over time, however, the muscle of this "decentralized bladder" regains activity, exhibiting numerous contraction waves that cause urine to dribble out of the urethra. Consequently, the bladder shrinks and its wall hypertrophies.

In this condition, when both afferent and efferent nerves are damaged the hyperactive state suggests the development of denervation hypersensitization. This occurs despite the interruption of preganglionic rather than postganglionic neurons.

In deafferentiation, where only the sensory fibers of the bladder are cut off, all the reflex contractions of the bladder are abolished and the bladder is distended, thin-walled and hypotonic. It can happen in tabes dorsalis.

questions.text:
12. A 50-year-old diabetic patient was brought to the emergency department in a semiconscious state with deep breaths. His RBG was 600 mg% and the Rothera's test was positive. Which of the following types of Oxygen-Hb dissociation curves is expected to be seen in this patient?

RBG- Random blood glucose
questions.solution:
The patient in the clinical scenario has diabetic ketoacidosis. Hence, a shift to the right (D) of the ODC curve is expected in this patient.

In diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), accumulation of ketoacids lowers blood pH, causing metabolic acidosis. The increased hydrogen ion concentration binds to hemoglobin and reduces its affinity for oxygen. This shifts the O₂–Hb dissociation curve to the right, enhancing oxygen unloading to peripheral tissues to meet metabolic demands.

The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve (OHDC) is a plot of the partial pressure of O2 and the % saturation of Hb with O2. It is normally sigmoid-shaped.

If OHDC is shifted to the right, it means that the affinity of Hb for O2 has become less (which favours O2 delivery) i.e. Higher the P50. (R - Right shift Releases oxygen). Shift to the right is caused by conditions with an increased requirement of O2 - metabolically active tissues as in:

* Hypoxia and Hypercarbia - Metabolically active tissues utilise O2, and tissues produce CO2

* ↓ pH - Secondary to increased CO2 production

* ↑ in temperature, heat 

* ↑ in 2,3-DPG - increased anaerobic glycolysis

* Growth hormone, thyroid hormone, androgen - by increasing 2,3 DPG

* Sickle cell anaemia - reduced affinity for O2

Interpretation of the curves:

* The curve marked 'A' is the ODC curve for myoglobin. It assumes the shape of a rectangular hyperbola.

* The curve marked 'C' is the normal ODC curve

* The curves 'B' and 'D' are the shift of the normal curve to the left and right, respectively

questions.text: 13. Therapeutic hypothermia is indicated in the treatment of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Therapeutic hypothermia is indicated in the treatment of hypoxic ischaemic encephalopathy (HIE).

HIE is a form of brain injury that occurs due to inadequate blood flow to the infant’s brain occurring as a result of a hypoxic-ischemic event during the prenatal, intrapartum, or postnatal period. This causes the accumulation of toxic metabolites and depletion of intra-cellular energy that further leads to neuronal injury and death.

Therapeutic Hypothermia involves systemic cooling to achieve a core temperature of 33.5°C within the first 6 hours after birth, for a period of 72 hours. This causes a reduction in the rate of production of toxic compounds and reduces seizure activity, thereby favoring cerebro-protection, especially in HIE due to intrapartum insult. It has been shown to reduce mortality and neuro-development impairment. In adults, therapeutic hypothermia also has a role in the treatment of cardiac arrest to prevent global cerebral ischemia.

The clinical grading is based on Sarnat & Sarnat Staging and HIE is described in three stages as shown below.

Signs Stage 1 Stage 2  Stage 3
Level of consciousness Hyperalert Lethargic Stuporous, comatose
Muscle tone Normal Hypotonic Flaccid
Posture Normal Flexion Decerebrate
Tendon reflex/clonus Hyperactive Hyperactive Absent
Myoclonus Present Present Absent
Moro reflex Strong Weak Absent
Pupils Mydriasis Miosis Unequal, poor light reflex
Seizures None Common Decerebration
EEG findings Normal Low voltage changing to seizure activity Burst suppression to isoelectric
Duration <24 hours if progress; otherwise, may remain normal 24 hours to 14 days Days to weeks
Outcome Good Variable Death, severe deficits    


Infants at >36 weeks of gestation with one out of the following four criteria, and in Sarnat stage 2 or 3 encephalopathy, may be started on therapeutic hypothermia

*

APGAR scores <5 at 10 minutes.

*

Positive pressure ventilation is required at ten minutes

*

Umbilical cord pH or any arterial pH <7, within 1 hour of life

* Base deficit of more than 16 mmol/L in cord blood or arterial blood within 1 hour of life

Therapeutic hypothermia should be started within 6 hours of birth and should not be continued till more than 72 hours after birth.

Other Options:

Option B: Febrile seizures are managed with anticonvulsants like lorazepam and midazolam. Antipyretics may be used to decrease the discomfort of the child but do not treat the seizures.

Option C: Malignant Hyperthermia is an anaesthetic complication and is managed using IV Dantrolene Sodium in sterile water. The use of ice packs for lowering the body temperature is indicated but only up to normal body temperature, and not to induce hypothermia.

Option D: Neonatal Hyperthermia may occur when an infant is exposed to high temperatures (radiant warmer, phototherapy) for prolonged periods and is managed by removing the infant from the source of heat, followed by cooling in a bath to the normal body temperature. Hypothermia or cooling devices are not indicated.

questions.text: 14. The agglutination test of a newborn baby born to a Rh-negative mother is given below. The baby is at the risk of having hemolytic reactions due to the presence of?
questions.solution:
The baby is at the risk of having hemolytic reactions due to the presence of the D antigen. 

The given agglutination test shows agglutination only with the Rh antiserum.  From the given agglutination test, the blood group of the baby is O-positive, as there is agglutination with the Rh antiserum, but no agglutination with A or B antisera. The Rh antigen is the D antigen.

Rh alloimmunization occurs when an Rh-negative mother produces antibodies to Rh antigens due to an Rh-positive fetus. In an Rh-positive individual, the presence of the D antigen is specific and carries antigenic properties responsible for hemolytic reactions. 

There are six common types of Rh antigens (C, D, E and c, d, e) each of which is called an Rh factor. The type D antigen is more antigenic than the others. Individuals who have the type D antigen are said to be Rh-positive, whereas those who don't have it are Rh-negative.

ABO blood typing is performed by mixing the individual's red blood cells with antisera that contains the various agglutinins on a slide and observing for the presence of clumping or agglutination. Determination of the baby's blood group in this case:

Step 1: Baby’s blood mixed with antisera A, B and D. Clumping indicates the presense of A, B or D antigen respectively. 

Step 2: Anti-A serum → No clumping → No A antigen

Step 3: Anti-B serum → No clumping → No B antigen

Interpretation: Blood group is O

Step 4: Anti-D serum → Clumping present → Rh (D) antigen present

Final Interpretation → Blood group is O+



Blood type Genotype

Agglutinogen

Agglutinins
A AA or OA A Anti-B
B BB or OB B Anti-A
O OO - Anti-A, Anti-B
AB AB A, B -


 

The H antigen is present in all four blood groups (A, B, AB, and O). A rare blood group where there is an absence of the H antigen is known as the Bombay blood group. Absence of this H antigen results in absence of A and B antigens. Their plasma contains anti-A, anti-B, and strong anti-H antibodies. Therefore, they do not react with anti-A, anti-B, and anti-AB antiserums, and get recognized as O blood group on cell typing.

However, the O blood group has an H antigen. Thus if a patient with the Bombay blood group is transfused with the O blood group blood, the anti-H antibodies in the Bombay blood group patient react with the H antigen present in the O blood group. This can lead to fatal transfusion reactions. Therefore, patients with the Bombay blood group require the same blood group during transfusion.  

Other less common systems of blood grouping include MNSs, Lutheran, Kell, and Kidd systems of blood grouping.

questions.text: 15. A young man experiences an acute onset of severe headache, breathlessness, and blurred vision while trekking on a mountain. Which of the following physiological factors has no role in this condition?

choices.text: Altered permeability of blood brain barrier
Release of calcium from endoplasmic reticulum
Increase in vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF)

questions.solution:
Release of calcium from endoplasmic reticulum has no role in the given scenario.

The above clinical scenario of acute onset of severe headache, breathlessness, and blurred vision while trekking on a mountain suggests high-altitude cerebral edema. Calcium release from the endoplasmic reticulum has no role in high-altitude cerebral edema.

At high altitudes, the partial pressure of oxygen in the atmosphere is low. When people ascend to high altitudes hypoxia causes systemic arteriolar dilatation. Consequently, the capillary pressure rises with increased transudation of fluid into the brain tissue and lungs. This results in cerebral edema and pulmonary edema respectively.

Pathophysiology: Vasogenic edema occurs due to the leaking of proteins and fluid through the blood-brain barrier (BBB). Causes of increased BBB permeability include:

* Mechanical factors- loss of autoregulation and increased capillary pressure due to increased sympathetic activity (option D).

* Increased chemical mediators of permeability- vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), nitric oxide, and cytokines (options A and C).

Patients with cerebral edema usually present with headache, and papilledema leading to a blurring of vision, breathlessness (due to hypoxia), nausea, and vomiting

Treatment involves the administration of oxygen and descent to a lower altitude. Nifedipine can be given as adjunct therapy.

Portable hyperbaric chambers are increasingly being used in the treatment of high-altitude illnesses when rapid descent is not possible. These chambers are available in armed forces hospitals in high-altitude areas.

Pearl PM1009: Acclimatization to high altitude

questions.text: 16. A young woman presents with impaired right-sided vision for the past 2 weeks. She is unable to see vehicles on the right side of her car. On examination, there is a deficit in the right half of her visual field in both eyes. What is the likely site of the lesion?
questions.solution:
The patient is having a visual deficit in the right vision i.e right homonymous hemianopia. The structure marked 3 i.e. the left optic tract is likely to be affected. 

In the given scenario, vision is lost in the right half of both eyes, which means:

* In the left eye, the nasal visual field is lost, and

* In the right eye, the temporal visual field is lost.

It means left temporal and right nasal fibres are destroyed which leads to right homonymous hemianopia. Anatomically, this can be explained by the fact that each optic tract contains fibres from the ipsilateral temporal half of the retina and the contralateral nasal half of the retina.

Homonymous hemianopia (HH) involves loss of vision on the same side of the visual field in both eyes. It is characteristically seen in lesions involving the visual pathway posterior to the optic chiasma.

HH may be either:

* Complete HH is characterised by the loss of the entire hemifield on the same side in both eyes

* Incomplete HH is characterised by partial loss of visual field on the same side in both eyes. Depending on whether the extent of partial loss of the visual field in both the eyes is the same or different, incomplete HH is classified as congruous or incongruous respectively. 

Other options:

Option A: The structure marked as 1 is the left optic nerve. A lesion in this part leads to blindness in the left eye.

Option B: The structure marked as 2 is the right optic nerve. A lesion in this part leads to blindness in the right eye.

Option D: The structure marked as 4 is the right optic tract. A lesion in this part leads to left homonymous hemianopia.

Pearl PM1950: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

* The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.

* A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.

* Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.

* A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).

* Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: 17. A 37-year-old woman presents with fatigue and easy bruisability for 3 months. She has a history of taking alternative medicine treatment for rheumatoid arthritis. On examination, her blood pressure is elevated. She has a moon face and buffalo hump, with wasting of limbs. What is the mechanism of action of the hormone that is elevated?
questions.solution:
This patient’s history and clinical examination suggest a diagnosis of exogenous Cushing’s syndrome in which cortisol is elevated which acts by binding to receptors in the cytoplasm.

Exogenous hypercortisolism due to the prolonged use of glucocorticoids (in this case- alternative medicine most likely containing glucocorticoid derivatives)and is the most common cause of Cushing's syndrome.

Excess cortisol increases the rate of gluconeogenesis, glycogenolysis, and insulin resistance. Cortisol directly affects the transcription and translation of enzyme proteins involved in the metabolism of fats, glycogen, protein synthesis, and Krebs' cycle. The excess catabolism of proteins causes purplish striae of the torso, osteoporosis, and poor wound healing.



Pearl PM0371: Mechanisms of Action of Hormones

Types of hormone receptors
Hormones that bind to intracellular receptors
Cytoplasmic receptors

Glucocorticoids

Minerolocorticoids

Androgens

Vitamin D
Nuclear receptors

Thyroid hormones

Vitamin A
Hormones that bind to cell surface receptors
1) G-protein coupled receptors (GPCR)
Gs: stimulation of second messenger cAMP

ACTH, CRH

TSH, GHRH

FSH, LH, hCG

Vasopressin (V2 receptors)

Catecholamines (β receptors)

Somatostatin

Glucagon

Secretin

Parathyroid hormone
Gi: inhibition of second messenger cAMP

Catecholamines (⍺2 receptors)

Acetylcholine (M2, M4)

Somatostatin
Gq: second messenger is phospholipase C or cGMP

second messenger is phospholipase C :

Catecholamines (⍺1 receptors)

GnRH, GHRH, TRH

Vasopressin (V1 receptor)

Gastrin

Cholecystokinin

Oxytocin

Acetylcholine (M1, M3, M5)

second messenger is cGMP:

Nitric Oxide

Atrial natriuretic peptide
2) Receptors using tyrosine kinase
JAK-STAT (non-receptor tyrosine kinase) 

Erythropoietin

Growth hormone

Prolactin
MAP kinase (receptor tyrosine kinase) pathway 

Growth factors like IGF, VEGF, FGF, PDGF

Insulin


Notes: 1. Although cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed, it moves to the nucleus to initiate its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors, as they bind and become activated in the nucleus, as mentioned above. However, they have two primary sites of action: the cytoplasm and the nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

Pearl PM1549: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Exogenous causes (iatrogenic)

* Prolonged administration of glucocorticoids (most common cause of Cushing's)

Endogenous causes

* ACTH independent (primary hypercortisolism)

* Adrenocortical adenoma 

* Adrenocortical carcinoma 

* Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia

* ACTH dependent (secondary hypercortisolism)

* Cushing’s disease: ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma (most common cause of endogenous Cushing's)

* Paraneoplastic causes: Ectopic ACTH secreting tumors

* Small-cell lung carcinoma

* Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors

* Medullary thyroid carcinoma

* Pheochromocytoma

Rare causes

* Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia

* Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease

* McCune – Albright syndrome

questions.text: 18. Which of the following Korotkoff sounds corresponds to diastolic blood pressure in a patient with aortic regurgitation?
questions.solution:
Muffled sound corresponds to diastolic blood pressure in aortic regurgitation.

In aortic regurgitation, the pulse pressure is widened and the Korotkoff sounds often do not disappear even when the sphygmomanometer cuff is fully deflated. Hence, diastolic pressure is recorded at the pressure that corresponds to muffling of korotkoff sounds.

Pearl PM0219: Phases of Korotkoff Sounds

Phase

Description

K-1

Tapping sound

Corresponds to systolic BP

K-2

Murmur (soft swishing sound)

K-3

Loud and clear tapping sound

K-4

Muffled sound

K-5

Disappearance of sounds

Corresponds to Diastolic BP


NOTE- K-4 (muffled sound) corresponds to DBP in-

* Adults after exercise

* Children

* Hyperthyroidism

* Aortic regurgitation

* Patients with arteriovenous fistulas for hemodialysis

questions.text: 19. Your friend tells you about his upcoming deep-sea diving trip. Which of the following is most likely to cause your friend to suffer from 'the bends'?

choices.text: The speed at which he ascends
The amount of time he spends underwater
The depth to which he dives

questions.solution:
A rapid speed of the ascent is most likely to cause a diver to suffer from decompression sickness, also called Caisson's disease, or 'the bends'.

As a diver goes deep underwater, the pressure of inert gases such as nitrogen, which is inspired, is increased and gets dissolved in the blood and tissues. Divers are advised to ascend slowly so that as they go from higher-pressure surroundings (deep) to lower-pressure surroundings (surface), the inert gases can equilibrate without expanding within the body.

Decompression sickness occurs when due to a sudden change in pressure, excess nitrogen, remains within the diver's blood and tissues, so that when they reach the surface, the low pressure allows the gas bubbles to expand within their body cavities, causing the symptoms of decompression sickness. (One can imagine the size of a bubble increasing as it rises from the bottom of a bottle/pool from the depth to the surface)

Decompression sickness is therefore prevented by having divers ascend gradually and take decompression stops where they spend some time at a certain depth and gradually ascend (a staircase pattern) to allow equilibration of the pressure and prevent the bubbles from expanding.

Spending longer time underwater (Option B), deeper dives (Option C) and colder temperatures (Option D) favour more nitrogen dissolving but it is the sudden change in pressure that is responsible for retention. Divers and pilots are also advised breaks between trips to prevent nitrogen accumulation.

Decompression sickness is treated in a decompression chamber where the patient is administered hyperbaric oxygen within a closed-pressurized chamber to allow the pressures to be equilibrated so they can be expired.

questions.text: 20. A man experienced a sudden syncopal episode when he tightened his necktie with a snug collar. After ruling out other causes, the physician suggests that the syncope resulted from stimulation of the carotid baroreceptor. Which of the following represents the changes caused by this receptor?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette represents a case of reflex syncope due to carotid sinus stimulation. The carotid sinus baroreceptor causes decreased sympathetic and increased parasympathetic discharge to the heart. 

Baroreceptors are stretch receptors located in the heart and the adventitia of the blood vessels. They are of two types - carotid sinus and aortic arch receptors (high-pressure regions) and cardiopulmonary receptors (low-pressure regions). 

Afferents:

* Carotid sinus receptor – a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX CN) – the carotid sinus nerve (sinus nerve of Hering)

* Aortic arch receptor – a branch of the vagus nerve (X CN) – aortic depressor nerve

Center for Reflex - Medulla (Nucleus Tractus solitarius)

Efferents- Sympathetic and parasympathetic neurons to the heart and vasculature

They are sensitive to mean arterial pressure. The threshold for excitation is 50-60 mmHg. They show maximal activity at around 180 mmHg. 

Carotid sinus reflex - Baroreceptors in carotid sinus and the aortic arch control blood pressure and heart rate. Pressure over them or an increased blood pressure increases the firing rate of baroreceptors and vagal activity which reduces the heart rate and reduces the blood pressure. Baroreceptor stimulation, by distension of the structures they are located in, inhibits the tonic discharge of sympathetic nerves and excites the vagal(parasympathetic) innervation of the heart. Thus leading to:

* Vasodilation and venodilation

* Hypotension

* Bradycardia(increased PR interval)

* Decrease in cardiac output

Clinical presentation of carotid sinus reflex - an abrupt loss of consciousness after pressure is over carotid baroreceptor. No prodromal symptoms are seen.
